Countries that use the Botswana pula

The Botswana pula was established in 1976 as an official national currency and is used only in Botswana. It replaced the previously valid South African rand. 1 Pula is devided into 100 Thebe.

The graph shown here shows the exchange rate development from January 2018 to March 2024. The exchange rate for 10 BWP moved during this time from USD 1.05 to USD 0.73. In these 74 months it fell by 29.9 percent.

Currency reserves for the Botswana pula

According to the International Monetary Fund, the total broad money (M3) amounted to BWP 109.96 billion at the end of 2023. For currency hedging, reserves were held in a total amount of 64.66 billion pulas. This corresponds to a ratio of 1:1.7. Or in other words, 10 of 17 pulas are deposited with a countervalue, which is internationally already above average.

All currency reserves are only held as foreign currencies, special drawing rights in the International Monetary Fund and other reserve positions. There are no governmental gold stocks.
